person.name: Shirley Cosby
person.social: married, living with husband and two sons

items.body:
Chief Complaint: increased cholesterol

History of Present Illness: Patient went to a health fair sponsored by her church and had her cholesterol level checked. It came back at 260 mg/dL and she was told to contact her physician. Patient doesn't recall having her cholesterol checked before. She eats a well-balanced diet and is not a fussy eater. She drinks low-fat milk, but otherwise has not particularly tried to avoid fat or cholesterol in her diet. She has gradually increased in weight over the years. When she was married, she weighed 57 kg. (125 lbs.)

Assessment: Hypercholesterolemia and overweight

Investigations: Lipid profile, fasting serum glucose, thyroid stimulating hormone, liver function tests just prior to return visit in 6 weeks

Medications and treatments: none

Follow-up and referral: Return in 6 weeks to review labs and progress

Patient education: Recommend lifestyle changes to reduce cholesterol and risk of cardiac disease, specifically dietary changes to lose weight and lower saturated fat and cholesterol in diet and increase exercise

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Somewhat overweight, pleasant and cooperative woman who appears her stated age. Eyes: PERRLA, optic disc sharp, no arteriolar narrowing, no exudates, hemorrhages. Carotids 2+ equal, no bruits. Cardiac: PMI not palpable, no heaves, thrills; S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs, gallops, or rubs. Chest: clear to percussion and auscultation. Abdomen: slightly protuberant, waist circumference 90 cm., bowel sounds present, no masses, no bruits. Extremities: d. pedis and posterior tibial 2+ and equal, no edema. Urine dipstick shows no sugar, blood, protein, and negative for leucocyte esterase.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: follow-up for cholesterol

History of Present Illness: Patient reports that she has been careful in her diet and has eliminated much of the saturated fat by avoiding cheese, red meat, and fat-containing dairy products. She is happy about the weight she has lost. She is also walking 2 km. a day.

Assessment: Total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol still above optimal levels despite patient's adherence to lifestyle changes and significant weight loss.

Investigations: Repeat liver function tests prior to next visit since she is beginning treatment with a statin today

Medications and treatments: lovastatin 20 mg. orally daily

Follow-up and referral: Return visit in 6 weeks

Patient education: Discussed the advisability of beginning a lipid-lowering drug while she continues her lifestyle changes since it appears that lifestyle changes alone will not be sufficient to lower her lipids into the normal range. The patient agrees to begin a statin.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Repeat fasting cholesterol still elevated at 221 mg/dL. LDL is above goal at 175.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: follow-up for cholesterol

History of Present Illness: Patient reports that she has continued to stick to her diet. She is also increased her walking to 3 km. a day. She has been taking lovastatin 20 mg. daily.

Assessment: Total cholesterol and LDL cholesterol still above goal. Further lowering indicated. LFTs normal.

Investigations: Repeat lipid panel and liver function tests just prior to next visit

Medications and treatments: Increase lovastatin to 40 mg. daily

Follow-up and referral: Return visit in 12 weeks

Patient education: Discussed lipid-lowering goals and why it was appropriate to increase dose of medications while continuing her lifestyle changes.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Repeat fasting cholesterol still elevated at 202 mg/dL. LDL is still above goal at 165.

items.body: History of Present Illness: Patient began to feel poor yesterday with vague abdominal pain and loss of appetite. She thought she had a stomach virus that would go away, but it continued to get worse. The pain became more severe, more localize to the upper right part of her abdomen, and the nausea also worsened and she vomited several times. Today she also developed a fever and the pain has continued to worsen and she has continued to vomit. She can barely move without excruciating pain.

Assessment: Acute cholecystitis

Investigations: Ultrasound of the abdomen, CBC, liver function tests

Medications and treatments: Intravenous hydration and opiate analgesics for pain; begin on cefuroxime and metronidazole antibiotics parenterally

Follow-up and referral: surgical referral

Patient education: informed patient and her family of the likelihood that this is an acute gallbladder attack and that surgery is likely to be needed

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Patient is in obvious pain. Chest is clear to percussion and auscultation. Cardiac: S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs. Abdomen: bowel sounds are present; diffusely tender to palpation with exquisite tenderness in right upper quadrant with severe pain brought on by inspiration while palpating under right costal margin (positive Murphy's sign).

results.name: testresults
results.title: Hematology, Coagulation, and Red Cell Enzymes

items.title: Consultation request from Dr. Steven Scrubs
items.body: Your patient, Shirley Cosby, was admitted to the hospital under my service a week ago for acute cholecystitis, which you diagnosed during her emergency room visit before referring to me. She underwent an emergency laparoscopic cholecystectomy the same day that went uneventfully. The gross pathology at surgery confirmed the diagnosis of acute cholecystitis. Her immediate postoperative course was uneventful and she was afebrile on the next postoperative day. On the second postoperative day, she developed a low grade fever (3738° C) and complained of nausea. As bowel sounds had not yet returned, she was kept NPO and on intravenous fluids. The same pattern of nausea, anorexia, absent bowel sounds, and variable low grade fever continued for the next 3 days (postop days 35) and she was kept NPO and fluid replacement. Yesterday, her fever spiked to 39.4° C and she began to complain of more abdominal pain. An infectious disease consultation was obtained and the consultant suggested that she be started on antibiotics. Cefazolin was initiated, but her temperature remains elevated. I would appreciate your seeing Ms. Cosby at your earliest possible convenience.

Chief Complaint: hostpital visit #1

History of Present Illness: Saw Ms. Cosby this afternoon at 3:20 P.M. She was ill-appearing and in considerable discomfort. Her sensorium seemed somewhat impaired, although she was able to respond to questions. She kept saying that she was dying and that her abdomen was hurting her a great deal. She said she was sick to her stomach.

Assessment: Possible sepsis, consider abscess in and around surgical site

Investigations: CT of the abdomen, blood and urine cultures, CBC

Medications and treatments: Begin on gentamycin and clindamycin after cultures obtained, begin parenteral nutrtional support, transfer to ICU for closer monitoring

Follow-up and referral: not applicable

Patient education: informed patient and her family of the possibility of an infection and that re-operation may be necessary

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Acutely ill-appearing, with clouded sensorium, but arousable. BP 80/50, pulse 110/min., respirations 30/min., temperature 40.3°C. Skin is cool and clammy with some mottling in the lower extremities. Chest: respirations shallow and rapid, some bibasilar rales, no dullness to percussion. Cardiac: S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs. Abdomen: incisions for fiberoptic portals clean and closed, bowel sounds absent, diffuse tenderness throughout with possibly some rebound tenderness, though the patient groans repeatedly with any maneuvers. CBC from this morning shows WBC 14,400 with 90.7% polys, hematocrit 36, hemoglobin 12.8, total protein 4.5, albumen 1.9, cholesterol 92. Portable chest x-ray showed some atelectasis but no consolidation, but the inspiratory effort was poor. Flat plate of the abdomen showed an ileus pattern.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: hospital visit #2

History of Present Illness: Was called to see Ms. Cosby because of a set back in her hospital course. One week ago, she underwent an exploratory laparotomy when the CT of her abdomen showed a phlegmon in the right upper quadrant. At surgery, an abscess was discovered as was a perforation in the right colic flexure. The abscess was drained and the perforation repaired. The next day the patient was markedly improved and has continued to recover slowly but steadily. The abscess culture was positive for bacteroides species. The blood culture was positive for E. coli.

The patient was treated with intravenous gentamycin and clindamycin to which the organisms were susceptible. Yesterday, the patient began to experience watery diarrhea. She says that she also began to feel generally more poorly, lost her appetite, developed nausea but has not vomited, and has felt feverish. She also complains of a return of abdominal pain which she describes as crampy.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body:
Patient is in discomfort, but is awake, alert, oriented, and cooperative. BP 100/78, pulse 90/min., respirations 20/min., temperature 38.50

C. Skin is moist with good turgor. Mucus membranes are moist. Chest: clear to auscultation and percussion. Cardiac: S1 and S2 normal, no murmurs. Abdomen: incisions for fiberoptic portals clean and closed, laparotomy incision in the midline is clean and closed with sutures in place, bowel sounds present, diffuse moderate tenderness throughout, no rebound tenderness, no masses appreciated. CBC yesterday shows WBC 13,200 with 82% polys, hematocrit 37, hemoglobin 12.9, total protein 4.9, albumen 2.3, cholesterol 140, Na+ 144, K+ 3.8, Cl- 102, HCO3- 28. Stool sent for culture, fecal leucocytes present on smear. Enzyme immunoassays for Toxin A and B were positive.

person.name: Naomi Nighthawk
person.social: Lives with her daughter and son-in-law

items.body:
Chief Complaint: weight loss

History of Present Illness: Patient accompanied by her daughter who is concerned about weight loss in her mother. Patient herself does not appear to be too concerned, saying that her appetite just isn't what it used to be and it's too much of a bother to always be eating something. Both patient and daughter agree that it has been very gradual and perhaps the patient has lost about 2 kg. in the past 6 months, but, as her daughter says, "she doesn't have much weight to spare." Her diet is fairly limited, consisting of toast with jam in the morning with tea, a half of a sandwich or salad for lunch usually with one slice of luncheon meat, and dinner which usually consists of some meat or fish, vegetable, and rice or potato, though she frequently only picks at her plate. She will have an occasional sweet. She does not drink any alcohol. The patient describes her general health as "what you'd expect for a 93-year-old," meaning that everything is slowing down and takes more energy to do. She had an eye exam within the past year and has new glasses. Her hearing is diminished, but she does not want a hearing aid. She walks with a cane around the house and stays on the ground floor where a room is set aside for her. She occupies herself with knitting, reading, listening to music, and watching television.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Patient is frail and slight but is able to ambulate slowly with her cane. She is very pleasant and cooperative, with a dry sense of humor, but reserved. Physical examination is essentially normal for her age. Specifically, her skin exam revealed no dangerous-appearing lesions, breasts were free of any masses, lungs were clear, heart sounds normal, and abdominal exam was benign. Office hematocrit was 34, urine dipstick was negative for protein, blood, sugar, and leukocyte esterase.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: follow-up for test results

History of Present Illness: Patient and daughter met with dietician and received some general suggestions on how to increase total calories in diet and how to increase intake of vitamin B12 and folate. Patient says she is trying to follow the advice and appreciates all the attention that everyone is giving her.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: CBC shows Hct 34, Hgb 10.2, RBC 3.0x106, MCHC 30, MCV 104, folate 0.7, B12 195, iron 45.

results.name: testresults
results.title: Hematology, Coagulation, and Red Cell Enzymes

items.body:
Chief Complaint: fainting

History of Present Illness: Daughter reports that her mother apparently fainted this morning. The daughter heard a thud in her mother's room and went in to find her mother on the floor in a dazed state. The patient doesn't recall what happened other than finding herself on the floor with her daughter. She thinks perhaps she arose too quickly from sitting, but isn't sure. She has occasionally felt very lightheaded and unsteady when getting up from lying down or sitting, but she has never before actually fainted. Her daughter estimates that it was less than a minute that her mother was not conscious. She did not sustain any injury from the faint that she can tell. The patient did not become incontinent of urine during the episode.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Patient appears unscathed from the incident. Neck is supple and full range of motion without producing symptoms. Carotids 2 and equal with no bruits. Cardiac exam remains unchanged with normal rhythm, S1 and S2, no murmurs. Extremities are nontraumatic and full range of motion without discomfort. Romberg negative. When patient is left lying for several minutes, BP is recorded at 138/82 and pulse is 72. One minute after assuming a standing position, BP is 105/66 and pulse is 76. Patient reports feeling somewhat lightheaded with that maneuver. Office electrocardiogram shows normal sinus rhythm, no evidence of heart block or frequent ectopic beats.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: follow-up for anemia

History of Present Illness: Patient says that she tries to follow the diet she was given, but finds it hard to eat that much. She doesn't have much of an appetite. She has been trying to drink more to avoid another fainting episode. She has not had another episode.

She reports recently having to ask for more help from her daughter. She finds it more difficult to do her usual activities and feels fatigued and weak. She has been relying on using her husband's old rolling walker because she does not feel steady any longer with her cane. Bathing has become difficult, and she is taking sponge baths. Her daughter now prepares the meals, does the shopping, and helps her get dressed in the morning.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: Patient seems somewhat frailer than previously noted, she appears cachectic on exam with temporal wasting, poor skin turgor and muscle wasting. Blood indices improved slightly.

results.title: Hematology, Coagulation, and Red Cell Enzymes

Ms. Nighthawk peacefully died at home 15 weeks after being admitted to Hospice Care.

items.body:
Chief Complaint: Acne

ticed acne getting worse on face and shoulders. Has tried some over-the-counter medications without much success.

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Benzoyl peroxide 2.5% a.m., after school and tretinoin cream 0.025% at bedtime

Follow-up and referrals: Return in 4-6 weeks

Patient education: Explained nature of acne

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body:
Moderate-to-moderately severe acne on face with many open and closed comedones, numerous papules and pustules, and a few inflammatory cysts, with a few inflammatory cysts on shoulders and upper back as well.

Papules/pustules +++/++

Nodules +

items.body:
Chief Complaint: Acne

History of Present Illness: Pt. says that acne has improved somewhat, but he is still concerned about it. Has been applying the benzoyl peroxide 2.5% solution in the morning and after school and tretinoin 0.025% cream at night. Initially the irritation was bothersome, but it improved after the first week.

Assessment: Acne somewhat improved, but not much and patient is concerned

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Add tetracycline 500 mg twice daily

Follow-up and referrals: Return in 4-6 weeks

Patient education: Provided encouragement, noted improvement

items.body:
Chief Complaint: Acne

History of Present Illness: Pt. says that acne has worsened since his last visit. He started the tetracycline and continues to take it. He wondered if the excessive sweating from football practice was having an effect. On further probing, he said that he was also taking anabolic steroids that were given to him by other football players as a way of bulking up. He says that has helped him put on some weight, though he's still lighter than most players.

Assessment: Acne exacerbated probably due to the anabolic steroids patient is using

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Maintain on current meds

Follow-up and referrals: Return in 4-6 weeks

Patient education: Counseled the patient about the dangers of anabolic steroids and their deleterious effect on acne. Encouraged patient to stop using steroids. Discussed risk-taking behavior in general and how to deal with it.

Chief Complaint: Hernia

History of Present Illness:

Hernia: The school doctor thinks patient has an inguinal hernia that was discovered during the football team's preseason physical. The patient was unaware of this. Until he's cleared by his family doctor, he can't participate in any live skirmishes or games, though he's allowed to practice with the team in noncontact drills.

Acne: Pt. stopped using steroid (he knew he'd never get to play first string anyway, he says, but at least his face would look better). Acne seems better, he thinks.

Assessment: Inguinal hernia. Acne improving.

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Maintain on current meds

Follow-up and referrals: Refer to surgeon for repair of hernia

Patient education: Explained nature of inguinal hernias

items.body:
Chief Complaint: f/u Acne

History of Present Illness: Patient says his acne is fine and he's stopped worrying about it. He did bring up another concern--his sexual orientation. He finds that he's attracted to other boys and at times becomes sexually aroused in the showers after track practice. He also has erotic dreams and fantasies about having sex with another boy on the team. He hasn't actually had any homosexual experiences, but thinks he's probably gay or maybe bisexual because he has had crushes on girls before, too. He wondered if the hernia condition he had was associated with a gay sexual orientation. He hasn't discussed this concern with anyone else. He thinks his father would "kill him" if he found out he was gay.

Assessment: Psychosexual concerns about sexual orientation. No evidence of depression or panic.

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Maintain on current meds for acne

Follow-up and referrals: Return in 6-12 weeks

Patient education: Counseled the patient about normal psychosexual development and offered empathetic listener; also, told him that there is no connection between having an inguinal hernia and sexual orientation

data.title: Phyiscal Examination
data.body:
Patient discussed the topic with some obvious embarrassment and awkwardness, but did not exhibit any signs of depression, though he was obviously concerned and worried. Acne status quo.

Papules/pustules +/rare

Nodules 0

items.body:
Chief Complaint: Breast Lump

History of Present Illness: Patient noticed a lump under his left breast and is concerned. It's slightly uncomfortable when he pushes on it or someone else does. He first noticed it when he had his first sexual experience with the other boy on the track team he previously talked about. His partner squeezed his breast hard and felt the lump, telling him that he was "growing a tit." This upset him. They had oral sex. He says he's pretty sure that he is gay and he's feeling more comfortable about that, but he hasn't told his parents or anyone else, for that matter. He said all this stuff (the hernia, his growing awareness of his sexual orientation, and now this breast lump) is really "messing up" his head.

Assessment: Gynecomastia, benign

Investigations: None

Medications and treatments: Maintain on current meds for acne

Follow-up and referrals: Return as needed

Patient education: Counseled the patient about gynecomastia, its common occurrence in males, and its likely natural history and prognosis. Also, counseled the patient about safe sex practices.

data.title: Physical Examination
data.body: A 3 cm. slightly tender firm disc-shaped mass is felt in the subareolar area in the left breast. No clear-cut mass is felt on the right. No lymphadenopathy is palpable. While patient is clearly worried about the mass, his speech is calm, his thoughts lucid and appropriate, and his mood is not overly anxious or depressed.
